metadata.author: Weicheng Liang, Zhijie Feng, Shitao Rao, Cuicui Xiao, Xingyang Xue, Zexiao Lin, Qi Zhang, Wei Qi
metadata.title: Diarrhoea may be underestimated: a missing link in 2019 novel coronavirus
metadata.abstract: Recent studies showed that the spike protein of 2019-nCoV shared the same cell entry receptor ACE2 as SARS-CoV.4 5 In terms of the pathological importance of ACE2 in modulating intestinal inflammation and diarrhoea,6 we examined the expression profiles of ACE2 in various human tissues and found that ACE2 was highly expressed in the human small intestine (online supplementary file 1). Intriguingly, the RNA level of ACE2 was quite low in lung tissues from healthy donors.

Intriguingly, the RNA level of ACE2 was quite low in lung tissues from healthy donors.

participants.context: To address this issue, we collected the data from three reports1–3 and compared the incidence accordingly. <mark class="stats">We found that the incidence of leucopenia, fever and diarrhoea in the three studies showed a statistically significant difference (table 1)</mark>. Among these symptoms, diarrhoea displayed the smallest p-value (p=0.016), suggesting that the criteria for diagnosing diarrhoea may differ in different hospitals

statistics.context: We found that the incidence of leucopenia, fever and diarrhoea in the three studies showed a statistically significant difference (table 1). <mark class="stats">Among these symptoms, diarrhoea displayed the smallest p-value (p=0.016), suggesting that the criteria for diagnosing diarrhoea may differ in different hospitals</mark>. Due to the different criteria, clinicians may underestimate the value of this symptom in clinical practice, and it may affect the preliminary diagnostic accuracy

summary: Recent studies showed that the spike protein of 2019-nCoV shared the same cell entry receptor ACE2 as SARS-CoV.4 5 In terms of the pathological importance of ACE2 in modulating intestinal inflammation and diarrhoea,6 the authors examined the expression profiles of ACE2 in various human tissues and found that ACE2 was highly expressed in the human small intestine.
A series of pneumonia cases caused by 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV, named COVID-19) are being reported globally.
Based on recent publications,1–3 the most common symptoms in patients infected by 2019-nCoV were fever and cough.
The incidence of other clinical features differs in different reports.
The authors collected the data from three reports1–3 and compared the incidence .
The authors found that the incidence of leucopenia, fever and diarrhoea in the three studies showed a statistically significant difference.
Diarrhoea displayed the smallest p-value (p=0.016), suggesting that the criteria for diagnosing diarrhoea may differ in different hospitals.
Due to the different criteria, clinicians may underestimate the value of this symptom in clinical practice, and it may affect the preliminary diagnostic accuracy.

Introduction: Recent studies showed that the spike protein of 2019-nCoV shared the same cell entry receptor ACE2 as SARS-CoV.4 5 In terms of the pathological importance of ACE2 in modulating intestinal inflammation and diarrhoea,6 the authors examined the expression profiles of ACE2 in various human tissues and found that ACE2 was highly expressed in the human small intestine.
A series of pneumonia cases caused by 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV, named COVID-19) are being reported globally.
Based on recent publications,1–3 the most common symptoms in patients infected by 2019-nCoV were fever and cough.
The incidence of other clinical features differs in different reports.
Results: The authors collected the data from three reports1–3 and compared the incidence .
The authors found that the incidence of leucopenia, fever and diarrhoea in the three studies showed a statistically significant difference.
Diarrhoea displayed the smallest p-value (p=0.016), suggesting that the criteria for diagnosing diarrhoea may differ in different hospitals.
Due to the different criteria, clinicians may underestimate the value of this symptom in clinical practice, and it may affect the preliminary diagnostic accuracy.
